subject: Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES); Threshold Electrical Stimulation (TES)
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Functional electrical stimulation (FES) is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications, including but not limited to:

  • When used to prevent or reverse muscular atrophy (wasting) and bone demineralization (loss), by stimulating paralyzed limbs for the performance of stationary exercise, or to correct gait disorders. This includes, but is not limited to, functional electrical stimulation ergometer devices (for example, ERGYS® and ERGYS® 2); or
  • When used to promote ambulation (for example, Parastep® I System); or
  • When used to activate muscles of the upper limb or lower limb to produce functional movement patterns. This includes, but is not limited to, the NESS H200® Handmaster Rehabilitation System, NESS L300™ Foot Drop System, ODFS Dropped Foot Stimulator, and the WalkAide® System.

    • Threshold electrical stimulation (TES) is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications including, but not limited to, treatment of motor disorders such as cerebral palsy or scoliosis.
content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications, including but not limited to:
  • When used to prevent or reverse muscular atrophy (wasting) and bone demineralization (loss), by stimulating paralyzed limbs for the performance of stationary exercise, or to correct gait disorders. This includes, but is not limited to, functional electrical stimulation ergometer devices (for example, ERGYS® and ERGYS® 2); or
  • When used to promote ambulation (for example, Parastep® I System); or
  • When used to activate muscles of the upper limb or lower limb to produce functional movement patterns. This includes, but is not limited to, the NESS H200® Handmaster Rehabilitation System, NESS L300™ Foot Drop System, ODFS Dropped Foot Stimulator, and the WalkAide® System.
    • Threshold electrical stimulation (TES) is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications including, but not limited to, treatment of motor disorders such as cerebral palsy or scoliosis.

subject: External Upper Limb Stimulation for the Treatment of Tremors
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Wrist-worn external upper limb tremor stimulator is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications, including but not limited to the treatment of essential tremor of the hands and Parkinson’s disease.

subject: Electrical Stimulation as a Treatment for Pain and Other Conditions: Surface and Percutaneous Devices
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Note: For examples of devices, see Types of Devices Used for Treatment in the Background/Overview section.

Electrical stimulation using the following techniques is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications:

  • Auricular electrostimulation
  • Cranial electrical stimulation (CES)
  • Electrical stimulation wound treatment device
  • Electromagnetic wound treatment device
  • H-Wave electrical stimulation devices
  • Interferential therapy (IF)
  • Microcurrent electrical nerve stimulation (MENS) devices
  • Non-implantable percutaneous neuromodulation therapy
  • Percutaneous electrical nerve field stimulation (PENFS)
  • Pulsed electrical stimulation
  • Pulsed electromagnetic field stimulation (PEMF)
  • Remote electrical neuromodulation (REN)
  • Supraorbital transcutaneous neurostimulation
  • Sympathetic Therapy
  • Transcutaneous electrical modulation pain reprocessing
content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary: Note: For examples of devices, see Types of Devices Used for Treatment in the Background/Overview section. Electrical stimulation using the following techniques is considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications:
  • Auricular electrostimulation
  • Cranial electrical stimulation (CES)
  • Electrical stimulation wound treatment device
  • Electromagnetic wound treatment device
  • H-Wave electrical stimulation devices
  • Interferential therapy (IF)
  • Microcurrent electrical nerve stimulation (MENS) devices
  • Non-implantable percutaneous neuromodulation therapy
  • Percutaneous electrical nerve field stimulation (PENFS)
  • Pulsed electrical stimulation
  • Pulsed electromagnetic field stimulation (PEMF)
  • Remote electrical neuromodulation (REN)
  • Supraorbital transcutaneous neurostimulation
  • Sympathetic Therapy
  • Transcutaneous electrical modulation pain reprocessing

subject: Self-Operated Spinal Unloading Devices
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Self-operated spinal unloading devices including, but not limited to, gravity-dependent and pneumatic devices, are considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications including, but not limited to, the treatment of low back pain and scoliosis.

subject: Cooling Devices and Combined Cooling/Heating Devices
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Active or passive cooling devices (with or without pneumatic compression or vibration) are considered investigational and not medically necessary for all uses, including but not limited to recovery after orthopedic surgery or trauma.

Active or passive devices that combine cooling and heating are considered investigational and not medically necessary for all uses.

Active or passive cooling devices (with or without pneumatic compression or vibration) are considered investigational and not medically necessary for all uses, including but not limited to recovery after orthopedic surgery or trauma.
Active or passive devices that combine cooling and heating are considered investigational and not medically necessary for all uses.

subject: Intrapulmonary Percussive Ventilation Devices
html_content:
Investigational and Not Medically Necessary:

Intrapulmonary percussive ventilation devices are considered investigational and not medically necessary for all indications, including but not limited to the following:

  • Cystic fibrosis; or
  • Bronchiectasis; or
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; or
  • Neuromuscular conditions associated with retained airway secretions or atelectasis.
  • Cystic fibrosis; or
  • Bronchiectasis; or
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; or
  • Neuromuscular conditions associated with retained airway secretions or atelectasis.
